# Milky Way

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the galaxy. For other uses, see [Milky Way
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Milky_Way_\(disambiguation\) "Milky Way
\(disambiguation\)").

The **Milky Way** is the [galaxy](/wiki/Galaxy "Galaxy")[21][22][23][nb 1]
that contains our [Solar System](/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System").[24] The
descriptive "milky" is derived from the appearance from Earth of the galaxy –
a band of light seen in the [night sky](/wiki/Night_sky "Night sky") formed
from stars that cannot be individually distinguished by the [naked
eye](/wiki/Naked_eye "Naked eye"). The term _Milky Way_ is a translation of
the [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") _via lactea_ , from the
[Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek") γαλαξίας κύκλος (_galaxías
kýklos_ , "milky circle").[25][26][27] From Earth, the Milky Way appears as a
band because its disk-shaped structure is viewed from within. [Galileo
Galilei](/wiki/Galileo_Galilei "Galileo Galilei") first resolved the band of
light into individual stars with his telescope in 1610. Until the early 1920s,
most astronomers thought that the Milky Way contained all the stars in the
[Universe](/wiki/Universe "Universe").[28] Following the 1920 [Great
Debate](/wiki/Great_Debate_\(astronomy\) "Great Debate \(astronomy\)") between
the astronomers [Harlow Shapley](/wiki/Harlow_Shapley "Harlow Shapley") and
[Heber Curtis](/wiki/Heber_Curtis "Heber Curtis"),[29] observations by [Edwin
Hubble](/wiki/Edwin_Hubble "Edwin Hubble") showed that the Milky Way is just
one of many galaxies.

The Milky Way is a [barred spiral galaxy](/wiki/Barred_spiral_galaxy "Barred
spiral galaxy") with a diameter between 100,000[30] and 180,000 [light-
years](/wiki/Light-year "Light-year").[31] The Milky Way is estimated to
contain 100–400 billion [stars](/wiki/Star "Star").[32][33] There are probably
at least 100 billion [planets](/wiki/Planets "Planets") in the Milky
Way.[34][35] The Solar System is located within the disk, about 26,000 light-
years from the [Galactic Center](/wiki/Galactic_Center "Galactic Center"), on
the inner edge of one of the spiral-shaped concentrations of gas and dust
called the [Orion Arm](/wiki/Orion_Arm "Orion Arm"). The stars in the inner
≈10,000 light-years form a [bulge](/wiki/Bulge_\(astronomy\) "Bulge
\(astronomy\)") and one or more bars that radiate from the bulge. The very
center is marked by an intense radio source, named [Sagittarius
A*](/wiki/Sagittarius_A* "Sagittarius A*"), which is likely to be a
[supermassive black hole](/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black
hole").

Stars and gases at a wide range of distances from the Galactic Center orbit at
approximately 220 kilometers per second. The constant rotation speed
contradicts the laws of [Keplerian
dynamics](/wiki/Kepler%27s_laws_of_planetary_motion "Kepler's laws of
planetary motion") and suggests that much of the [mass](/wiki/Mass "Mass") of
the Milky Way does not emit or absorb [electromagnetic
radiation](/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation "Electromagnetic radiation"). This
mass has been termed "[dark matter](/wiki/Dark_matter "Dark matter")".[36] The
rotational period is about 240 million years at the position of the Sun.[18]
The Milky Way as a whole is moving at a velocity of approximately 600 km per
second with respect to extragalactic frames of reference. The oldest stars in
the Milky Way are nearly as old as the Universe itself and thus probably
formed shortly after the [Dark
Ages](/wiki/Chronology_of_the_universe#Dark_Ages "Chronology of the universe")
of the [Big Bang](/wiki/Big_Bang "Big Bang").[9]

The Milky Way has several [satellite
galaxies](/wiki/List_of_Milky_Way%27s_satellite_galaxies "List of Milky Way's
satellite galaxies") and is part of the [Local Group](/wiki/Local_Group "Local
Group") of galaxies, which is a component of the [Virgo
Supercluster](/wiki/Virgo_Supercluster "Virgo Supercluster"), which is itself
a component of the [Laniakea Supercluster](/wiki/Laniakea_Supercluster
"Laniakea Supercluster").[37][38]

## Appearance

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Milky_Way_Night_Sky_Black_Rock_Desert_Nevada.jpg/220px-
Milky_Way_Night_Sky_Black_Rock_Desert_Nevada.jpg)](/wiki/File:Milky_Way_Night_Sky_Black_Rock_Desert_Nevada.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Milky_Way_Night_Sky_Black_Rock_Desert_Nevada.jpg "Enlarge")

A view of the Milky Way toward the constellation
[Sagittarius](/wiki/Sagittarius_\(constellation\) "Sagittarius
\(constellation\)") (including the [Galactic Center](/wiki/Galactic_Center
"Galactic Center")) as seen from an area not polluted by light (the [Black
Rock Desert](/wiki/Black_Rock_Desert "Black Rock Desert"), Nevada). The bright
object on the right is Jupiter, just above [Antares](/wiki/Antares "Antares").

ALMA.webm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Following_the_Milky_Way_over_ALMA.webm/220px

This time-lapse video captures the Milky Way circling over

The "Milky Way" can be seen as a hazy band of white light some 30 degrees wide
arcing across the sky.[39] Although all the individual naked-eye
[stars](/wiki/Star "Star") in the entire sky are part of the Milky
Way,[40][41] the light in this band originates from the accumulation of
[unresolved](/wiki/Angular_resolution "Angular resolution") stars and other
material located in the direction of the [galactic plane](/wiki/Galactic_plane
"Galactic plane"). Dark regions within the band, such as the [Great
Rift](/wiki/Great_Rift_\(astronomy\) "Great Rift \(astronomy\)") and the
[Coalsack](/wiki/Coalsack_Nebula "Coalsack Nebula"), are areas where light
from distant stars is blocked by [interstellar dust](/wiki/Interstellar_dust
"Interstellar dust"). The area of the sky obscured by the Milky Way is called
the [Zone of Avoidance](/wiki/Zone_of_Avoidance "Zone of Avoidance").

The Milky Way has a relatively low [surface
brightness](/wiki/Surface_brightness "Surface brightness"). Its visibility can
be greatly reduced by background light such as [light
pollution](/wiki/Light_pollution "Light pollution") or stray light from the
[Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon"). The sky needs to be darker than about 20.2
[magnitude](/wiki/Magnitude_\(astronomy\) "Magnitude \(astronomy\)") per
square arcsecond in order for the Milky Way to be seen.[42] It should be
visible when the [limiting magnitude](/wiki/Limiting_magnitude "Limiting
magnitude") is approximately +5.1 or better and shows a great deal of detail
at +6.1.[43] This makes the Milky Way difficult to see from any brightly lit
urban or suburban location, but very prominent when viewed from a rural area
when the Moon is below the horizon.[nb 2] The new world atlas of artificial
night sky brightness shows that more than one-third of Earth's population
cannot see the Milky Way from their homes due to light pollution.[44]

As viewed from Earth, the visible region of the Milky Way's Galactic plane
occupies an area of the sky that includes 30
[constellations](/wiki/Constellation "Constellation").[45] The [center of the
Galaxy](/wiki/Galactic_center "Galactic center") lies in the direction of the
constellation [Sagittarius](/wiki/Sagittarius_\(constellation\) "Sagittarius
\(constellation\)"); it is here that the Milky Way is brightest. From
Sagittarius, the hazy band of white light appears to pass around to the
[Galactic anticenter](/wiki/Galactic_anticenter "Galactic anticenter") in
[Auriga](/wiki/Auriga_\(constellation\) "Auriga \(constellation\)"). The band
then continues the rest of the way around the sky, back to Sagittarius. The
band divides the night sky into two roughly equal
[hemispheres](/wiki/Celestial_sphere "Celestial sphere").

The Galactic plane is inclined by about 60 degrees to the
[ecliptic](/wiki/Ecliptic "Ecliptic") (the plane of Earth's orbit). Relative
to the [celestial equator](/wiki/Celestial_equator "Celestial equator"), it
passes as far north as the constellation of
[Cassiopeia](/wiki/Cassiopeia_\(constellation\) "Cassiopeia
\(constellation\)") and as far south as the constellation of [Crux](/wiki/Crux
"Crux"), indicating the high inclination of Earth’s [equatorial
plane](/wiki/Equator "Equator") and the plane of the ecliptic, relative to the
Galactic plane. The north Galactic pole is situated at [right
ascension](/wiki/Right_ascension "Right ascension") 12h 49m,
[declination](/wiki/Declination "Declination") +27.4° ([B1950](/wiki/B1950
"B1950")) near [β Comae Berenices](/wiki/Beta_Comae_Berenices "Beta Comae
Berenices"), and the south Galactic pole is near [α
Sculptoris](/wiki/Alpha_Sculptoris "Alpha Sculptoris"). Because of this high
inclination, depending on the time of night and year, the arc of the Milky Way
may appear relatively low or relatively high in the sky. For observers from
approximately 65 degrees north to 65 degrees south on Earth's surface, the
Milky Way passes directly overhead twice a day.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Milky_Way_Arch.jpg/600px-
Milky_Way_Arch.jpg)](/wiki/File:Milky_Way_Arch.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Milky_Way_Arch.jpg "Enlarge")

The Milky Way arching at a high inclination across the night sky _([fish-
eye](/wiki/Fisheye_lens "Fisheye lens") mosaic shot at
[Paranal](/wiki/Paranal_Observatory "Paranal Observatory"), Chile)_. The
bright object is Jupiter in the constellation
[Sagittarius](/wiki/Sagittarius_\(constellation\) "Sagittarius
\(constellation\)"), and the [Magellanic Clouds](/wiki/Magellanic_Clouds
"Magellanic Clouds") can be seen on the left. Galactic north is downwards.

## Size and mass

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/UGC_12158.jpg/300px-
UGC_12158.jpg)](/wiki/File:UGC_12158.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:UGC_12158.jpg "Enlarge")

A photograph of galaxy [UGC 12158](/wiki/UGC_12158 "UGC 12158"), which is
thought to resemble the Milky Way in appearance.

The Milky Way is the second-largest galaxy in the [Local
Group](/wiki/Local_Group "Local Group"), with its stellar disk approximately
100,000 ly (30 kpc) in diameter, and, on average, approximately 1,000 ly (0.3
kpc) thick.[4][5] As a guide to the relative physical scale of the Milky Way,
if the Solar System out to [Neptune](/wiki/Neptune "Neptune") were the size of
a US quarter (24.3 mm (0.955 in)), the Milky Way would be approximately the
size of the continental United States.[46] A ring-like filament of stars
wrapping around the Milky Way may belong to the Milky Way itself, rippling
above and below the relatively flat galactic plane.[31] If so, that would mean
a diameter of 150,000–180,000 light-years (46–55 kpc).[47]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Milky_way_profile.svg/192px-
Milky_way_profile.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Milky_way_profile.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Milky_way_profile.svg "Enlarge")

Schematic profile of the Milky Way.

Estimates of the mass of the Milky Way vary, depending upon the method and
data used. At the low end of the estimate range, the mass of the Milky Way is
5.8×1011 [solar masses](/wiki/Solar_mass "Solar mass") (M☉), somewhat less
than that of the [Andromeda Galaxy](/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy "Andromeda
Galaxy").[48][49][50] Measurements using the [Very Long Baseline
Array](/wiki/Very_Long_Baseline_Array "Very Long Baseline Array") in 2009
found velocities as large as 254 km/s (570,000 mph) for stars at the outer
edge of the Milky Way.[51] Because the orbital velocity depends on the total
mass inside the orbital radius, this suggests that the Milky Way is more
massive, roughly equaling the mass of Andromeda Galaxy at 7×1011 M☉ within
160,000 ly (49 kpc) of its center.[52] In 2010, a measurement of the radial
velocity of halo stars found that the mass enclosed within 80
kilo[parsecs](/wiki/Parsec "Parsec") is 7×1011 M☉.[53] According to a study
published in 2014, the mass of the entire Milky Way is estimated to be
8.5×1011 M☉,[54] which is about half the mass of the Andromeda Galaxy.[54]

Much of the mass of the Milky Way appears to be [dark
matter](/wiki/Dark_matter "Dark matter"), an unknown and invisible form of
matter that interacts gravitationally with ordinary matter. A [dark matter
halo](/wiki/Dark_matter_halo "Dark matter halo") is spread out relatively
uniformly to a distance beyond one hundred kiloparsecs from the Galactic
Center. Mathematical models of the Milky Way suggest that the mass of dark
matter is 1–1.5×1012 M☉.[10][11][55] Recent studies indicate a range in mass,
as large as 4.5×1012 M☉ [56] and as small as 8×1011 M☉.[57]

The total mass of all the stars in the Milky Way is estimated to be between
4.6×1010 M☉[58] and 6.43×1010 M☉.[10] In addition to the stars, there is also
interstellar gas, comprising 90% [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen") and 10%
[helium](/wiki/Helium "Helium") by mass,[59] with two thirds of the hydrogen
found in the [atomic form](/wiki/Neutral_hydrogen "Neutral hydrogen") and the
remaining one-third as [molecular hydrogen](/wiki/Molecular_hydrogen
"Molecular hydrogen").[60] The mass of this gas is equal to between 10%[60]
and 15%[59] of the total mass of the galaxy's stars. [Interstellar
dust](/wiki/Interstellar_dust "Interstellar dust") accounts for an additional
1% of the total mass of the gas.[59]

## Contents

Further information: [Exoplanet](/wiki/Exoplanet "Exoplanet")

The Milky Way contains between 200 and 400 billion stars[61][62] and at least
100 billion planets.[63] The exact figure depends on the number of very-low-
mass stars, which are hard to detect, especially at distances of more than 300
ly (90 pc) from the Sun. As a comparison, the neighboring Andromeda Galaxy
contains an estimated one trillion (1012) stars.[64] Filling the space between
the stars is a disk of gas and dust called the [interstellar
medium](/wiki/Interstellar_medium "Interstellar medium"). This disk has at
least a comparable extent in radius to the stars,[65] whereas the thickness of
the gas layer ranges from hundreds of light years for the colder gas to
thousands of light years for warmer gas.[66][67]

The disk of stars in the Milky Way does not have a sharp edge beyond which
there are no stars. Rather, the concentration of stars decreases with distance
from the center of the Milky Way. For reasons that are not understood, beyond
a radius of roughly 40,000 ly (13 kpc) from the center, the number of stars
per cubic [parsec](/wiki/Parsec "Parsec") drops much faster with radius.[68]
Surrounding the galactic disk is a spherical [Galactic
Halo](/wiki/Galactic_Halo "Galactic Halo") of stars and [globular
clusters](/wiki/Globular_clusters "Globular clusters") that extends further
outward but is limited in size by the orbits of two Milky Way satellites, the
Large and Small [Magellanic Clouds](/wiki/Magellanic_Clouds "Magellanic
Clouds"), whose [closest approach](/wiki/Apsis "Apsis") to the Galactic Center
is about 180,000 ly (55 kpc).[69] At this distance or beyond, the orbits of
most halo objects would be disrupted by the Magellanic Clouds. Hence, such
objects would probably be ejected from the vicinity of the Milky Way. The
integrated [absolute visual magnitude](/wiki/Absolute_visual_magnitude
"Absolute visual magnitude") of the Milky Way is estimated to be around
−20.9.[70][71][a]

Both [gravitational microlensing](/wiki/Gravitational_microlensing
"Gravitational microlensing") and planetary transit observations indicate that
there may be at least as many planets bound to stars as there are stars in the
Milky Way,[34][72] and microlensing measurements indicate that there are more
[rogue planets](/wiki/Rogue_planet "Rogue planet") not bound to host stars
than there are stars.[73][74] The Milky Way contains at least one planet per
star, resulting in 100–400 billion planets, according to a January 2013 study
of the five-planet star system [Kepler-32](/wiki/Kepler-32 "Kepler-32") with
the [Kepler](/wiki/Kepler_\(spacecraft\) "Kepler \(spacecraft\)") space
observatory.[35] A different January 2013 analysis of Kepler data estimated
that at least 17 billion [Earth-sized](/wiki/Terrestrial_planet "Terrestrial
planet") [exoplanets](/wiki/Exoplanets "Exoplanets") reside in the Milky
Way.[75] On November 4, 2013, astronomers reported, based on [_Kepler_ space
mission](/wiki/Kepler_\(spacecraft\) "Kepler \(spacecraft\)") data, that there
could be as many as 40 billion Earth-sized [planets](/wiki/Extrasolar_planet
"Extrasolar planet") orbiting in the [habitable zones](/wiki/Habitable_zone
"Habitable zone") of [Sun-like stars](/wiki/Solar_analog "Solar analog") and
[red dwarfs](/wiki/Red_dwarf "Red dwarf") within the Milky Way.[76][77][78] 11
billion of these estimated planets may be orbiting Sun-like stars.[79] The
nearest such planet may be 4.2 light-years away, according to a 2016
study.[80] Such Earth-sized planets may be more numerous than gas giants.[34]
Besides exoplanets, "[exocomets](/wiki/Exocomet "Exocomet")",
[comets](/wiki/Comets "Comets") beyond the Solar System, have also been
detected and may be common in the Milky Way.[81]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/ESO_-_The_Milky_Way_panorama_%28by%29.jpg/825px-ESO_-_The_Milky_Way_panorama_%28by%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:ESO_-_The_Milky_Way_panorama_\(by\).jpg)

_[Spitzer](/wiki/Spitzer_Space_Telescope "Spitzer Space Telescope")_ reveals
what cannot be seen in visible light: cooler stars (blue), heated dust
(reddish hue), and [Sgr A*](/wiki/Sagittarius_A* "Sagittarius A*") as bright
white spot in the middle.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/X-RayFlare-BlackHole-
MilkyWay-20140105.jpg/220px-X-RayFlare-BlackHole-
MilkyWay-20140105.jpg)](/wiki/File:X-RayFlare-BlackHole-MilkyWay-20140105.jpg)

Bright [X-ray](/wiki/X-ray "X-ray") flares from [Sagittarius
A*](/wiki/Sagittarius_A* "Sagittarius A*"), location of the [supermassive
black hole](/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black hole") at the
center of the Milky Way.[83]

The Milky Way consists of a bar-shaped core region surrounded by a disk of
[gas, dust](/wiki/Interstellar_medium "Interstellar medium") and stars. The
mass distribution within the Milky Way closely resembles the type Sbc in the
[Hubble classification](/wiki/Hubble_sequence "Hubble sequence"), which
represents spiral galaxies with relatively loosely wound arms.[1] Astronomers
began to suspect that the Milky Way is a [barred spiral
galaxy](/wiki/Barred_spiral_galaxy "Barred spiral galaxy"), rather than an
ordinary [spiral galaxy](/wiki/Spiral_galaxy "Spiral galaxy"), in the
1990s.[84] Their suspicions were confirmed by the [Spitzer Space
Telescope](/wiki/Spitzer_Space_Telescope "Spitzer Space Telescope")
observations in 2005[85] that showed the Milky Way's central bar to be larger
than previously thought.

### Galactic quadrants

Main article: [Galactic quadrant](/wiki/Galactic_quadrant "Galactic quadrant")

A galactic quadrant, or quadrant of the Milky Way, refers to one of four
circular sectors in the division of the Milky Way. In actual astronomical
practice, the delineation of the galactic quadrants is based upon the
[galactic coordinate system](/wiki/Galactic_coordinate_system "Galactic
coordinate system"), which places the [Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun") as the [origin of
the mapping system](/wiki/Polar_coordinates "Polar coordinates").[86]

Quadrants are described using [ordinals](/wiki/Ordinal_number_\(linguistics\)
"Ordinal number \(linguistics\)")—for example, "1st galactic quadrant",[87]
"second galactic quadrant",[88] or "third quadrant of the Milky Way".[89]
Viewing from the [north galactic pole](/wiki/North_galactic_pole "North
galactic pole") with 0 [degrees](/wiki/Degree_\(angle\) "Degree \(angle\)")
(°) as the [ray](/wiki/Ray_\(geometry\) "Ray \(geometry\)") that runs starting
from the Sun and through the Galactic Center, the quadrants are as follows:

  * 1st galactic quadrant – 0° ≤ [longitude](/wiki/Galactic_longitude "Galactic longitude") (ℓ) ≤ 90°[90]
  * 2nd galactic quadrant – 90° ≤ ℓ ≤ 180°[88]
  * 3rd galactic quadrant – 180° ≤ ℓ ≤ 270°[89]
  * 4th galactic quadrant – 270° ≤ ℓ ≤ 360° (0°)[87]

### Galactic Center

Main article: [Galactic Center](/wiki/Galactic_Center "Galactic Center")

The Sun is 25,000–28,000 ly (7.7–8.6 kpc) from the Galactic Center. This value
is estimated using [geometric](/wiki/Geometric "Geometric")-based methods or
by measuring selected astronomical objects that serve as [standard
candles](/wiki/Standard_candles "Standard candles"), with different techniques
yielding various values within this approximate range.[15][16][17][91][92][93]
In the inner few kpc (around 10,000 light-years radius) is a dense
concentration of mostly old stars in a roughly spheroidal shape called [the
bulge](/wiki/Bulge_\(astronomy\) "Bulge \(astronomy\)").[94] It has been
proposed that the Milky Way lacks a
[bulge](/wiki/Galactic_bulge#Classical_bulges "Galactic bulge") formed due to
a [collision and merger between previous galaxies](/wiki/Galactic_merger
"Galactic merger"), and that instead it has a
[_pseudobulge_](/wiki/Galactic_bulge#Disk-like_Bulges "Galactic bulge") formed
by its central bar.[95]

The Galactic Center is marked by an intense [radio
source](/wiki/Radio_astronomy "Radio astronomy") named [Sagittarius
A*](/wiki/Sagittarius_A* "Sagittarius A*") (pronounced Sagittarius A-star).
The motion of material around the center indicates that Sagittarius A* harbors
a massive, compact object.[96] This concentration of mass is best explained as
a [supermassive black hole](/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black
hole")[nb 3][15][97] (SMBH) with an estimated mass of 4.1–4.5 million times
the [mass of the Sun](/wiki/Solar_mass "Solar mass").[97] The rate of
accretion of the SMBH is consistent with an [inactive galactic
nucleus](/wiki/Active_galactic_nucleus "Active galactic nucleus"), being
estimated at around 6995100000000000000♠1×10−5 M☉ y−1.[98] Observations
indicate that there are SMBH located near the center of most normal
galaxies.[99][100]

The nature of the Milky Way's bar is actively debated, with estimates for its
half-length and orientation spanning from 1 to 5 kpc (3,000–16,000 ly) and
10–50 degrees relative to the line of sight from Earth to the Galactic
Center.[92][93][101] Certain authors advocate that the Milky Way features two
distinct bars, one nestled within the other.[102] However, [RR Lyrae
variables](/wiki/RR_Lyrae_variable "RR Lyrae variable") do not trace a
prominent Galactic bar.[93][103][104] The bar may be surrounded by a ring
called the "5-kpc ring" that contains a large fraction of the molecular
hydrogen present in the Milky Way, as well as most of the Milky Way's [star
formation](/wiki/Star_formation "Star formation") activity. Viewed from the
Andromeda Galaxy, it would be the brightest feature of the Milky Way.[105]
X-ray emission from the core is aligned with the massive stars surrounding the
central bar[98] and the [Galactic ridge](/wiki/Galactic_ridge "Galactic
ridge").[106]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/800_nasa_structure_renderin2.jpg/220px-800_nasa_structure_renderin2.jpg)](/wiki/File:800_nasa_structure_renderin2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:800_nasa_structure_renderin2.jpg "Enlarge")

Illustration of the two gigantic [X-ray](/wiki/X-ray "X-ray")/[gamma-
ray](/wiki/Gamma-ray "Gamma-ray") bubbles (blue-violet) of the Milky Way
(center)

In 2010, two gigantic spherical bubbles of high energy emission were detected
to the north and the south of the Milky Way core, using data from the [Fermi
Gamma-ray Space Telescope](/wiki/Fermi_Gamma-ray_Space_Telescope "Fermi Gamma-
ray Space Telescope"). The diameter of each of the bubbles is about 25,000
light-years (7.7 kpc); they stretch up to [Grus](/wiki/Grus_\(constellation\)
"Grus \(constellation\)") and to [Virgo](/wiki/Virgo_\(constellation\) "Virgo
\(constellation\)") on the night-sky of the southern hemisphere.[107][108]
Subsequently, observations with the [Parkes Telescope](/wiki/Parkes_Telescope
"Parkes Telescope") at radio frequencies identified polarized emission that is
associated with the Fermi bubbles. These observations are best interpreted as
a magnetized outflow driven by star formation in the central 640 ly (200 pc)
of the Milky Way.[109]

Later, on January 5, 2015, [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA") reported observing an
[X-ray](/wiki/X-ray "X-ray") flare 400 times brighter than usual, a record-
breaker, from Sagittarius A*. The unusual event may have been caused by the
breaking apart of an [asteroid](/wiki/Asteroid "Asteroid") falling into the
black hole or by the entanglement of [magnetic field
lines](/wiki/Magnetic_field_lines "Magnetic field lines") within gas flowing
into Sagittarius A*.[83]

### Spiral arms

For more details on this topic, see [Spiral galaxy](/wiki/Spiral_galaxy
"Spiral galaxy").

Outside the gravitational influence of the Galactic bars, the structure of the
interstellar medium and stars in the disk of the Milky Way is organized into
four spiral arms.[110] Spiral arms typically contain a higher density of
interstellar gas and dust than the Galactic average as well as a greater
concentration of star formation, as traced by [H II regions](/wiki/H_II_region
"H II region")[111][112] and [molecular clouds](/wiki/Molecular_cloud
"Molecular cloud").[113]

The Milky Way's spiral structure is uncertain, and there is currently no
consensus on the nature of the Milky Way's spiral arms.[82] Perfect
logarithmic spiral patterns only crudely describe features near the
Sun,[112][114] because galaxies commonly have arms that branch, merge, twist
unexpectedly, and feature a degree of irregularity.[93][114][115] The possible
scenario of the Sun within a spur / Local arm[112] emphasizes that point and
indicates that such features are probably not unique, and exist elsewhere in
the Milky Way.[114] Estimates of the pitch angle of the arms range from about
7° to 25°.[65][116] There are thought to be four spiral arms that all start
near the Milky Way's center.[117] These are named as follows, with the
positions of the arms shown in the image at right:

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Milky_Way_Arms.svg/220px-
Milky_Way_Arms.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Milky_Way_Arms.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Milky_Way_Arms.svg "Enlarge")

Observed (normal lines) and extrapolated (dotted lines) structure of the
spiral arms. The gray lines radiating from the Sun's position (upper center)
list the three-letter abbreviations of the corresponding constellations.

Color | Arm(s)  
---|---  
cyan | 3-kpc Arm ([Near 3 kpc Arm](/wiki/Near_3_kpc_Arm "Near 3 kpc Arm") and [Far 3 kpc Arm](/wiki/Far_3_kpc_Arm "Far 3 kpc Arm")) and [Perseus Arm](/wiki/Perseus_Arm "Perseus Arm")  
purple | [Norma](/wiki/Norma_Arm "Norma Arm") and [Outer arm](/wiki/Outer_arm "Outer arm") (Along with extension discovered in 2004[118])  
green | [Scutum–Centaurus Arm](/wiki/Scutum%E2%80%93Centaurus_Arm "Scutum–Centaurus Arm")  
pink | [Carina–Sagittarius Arm](/wiki/Carina%E2%80%93Sagittarius_Arm "Carina–Sagittarius Arm")  
_There are at least two smaller arms or spurs, including:_  
orange | [Orion–Cygnus Arm](/wiki/Orion%E2%80%93Cygnus_Arm "Orion–Cygnus Arm") (which contains the Sun and Solar System)  
  
Two spiral arms, the Scutum–Centaurus arm and the Carina–Sagittarius arm, have
tangent points inside the Sun's orbit about the center of the Milky Way. If
these arms contain an overdensity of stars compared to the average density of
stars in the Galactic disk, it would be detectable by counting the stars near
the tangent point. Two surveys of near-infrared light, which is sensitive
primarily to red giants and not affected by dust extinction, detected the
predicted overabundance in the Scutum–Centaurus arm but not in the
Carina–Sagittarius arm: the Scutum-Centaurus Arm contains approximately 30%
more [red giants](/wiki/Red_giant "Red giant") than would be expected in the
absence of a spiral arm.[116][119] This observation suggests that the Milky
Way possesses only two major stellar arms: the Perseus arm and the
Scutum–Centaurus arm. The rest of the arms contain excess gas but not excess
old stars.[82] In December 2013, astronomers found that the distribution of
young stars and star-forming regions matches the four-arm spiral description
of the Milky Way.[120][121][122] Thus, the Milky Way appears to have two
spiral arms as traced by old stars and four spiral arms as traced by gas and
young stars. The explanation for this apparent discrepancy is unclear.[122]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/PIA19341-MilkyWayGalaxy-
SpiralArmsData-WISE-20150603.jpg/200px-PIA19341-MilkyWayGalaxy-SpiralArmsData-
WISE-20150603.jpg)](/wiki/File:PIA19341-MilkyWayGalaxy-SpiralArmsData-
WISE-20150603.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PIA19341-MilkyWayGalaxy-SpiralArmsData-WISE-20150603.jpg
"Enlarge")

Clusters detected by [WISE](/wiki/Wide-field_Infrared_Survey_Explorer "Wide-
field Infrared Survey Explorer") used to trace the Milky Way's spiral arms

The Near 3 kpc Arm (also called Expanding 3 kpc Arm or simply 3 kpc Arm) was
discovered in the 1950s by astronomer van Woerden and collaborators through
[21-centimeter](/wiki/Hydrogen_line "Hydrogen line") radio measurements of HI
([atomic hydrogen](/wiki/Atomic_hydrogen "Atomic hydrogen")).[123][124] It was
found to be expanding away from the central bulge at more than 50
[km/s](/wiki/Kilometer_per_second "Kilometer per second"). It is located in
the fourth galactic quadrant at a distance of about 5.2 [kpc](/wiki/Parsec
"Parsec") from the [Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun") and 3.3 kpc from the [Galactic
Center](/wiki/Galactic_Center "Galactic Center"). The Far 3 kpc Arm was
discovered in 2008 by astronomer Tom Dame (Harvard-Smithsonian CfA). It is
located in the first galactic quadrant at a distance of 3 [kpc](/wiki/Parsec
"Parsec") (about 10,000 [ly](/wiki/Light_year "Light year")) from the Galactic
Center.[124][125]

A simulation published in 2011 suggested that the Milky Way may have obtained
its spiral arm structure as a result of repeated collisions with the
[Sagittarius Dwarf Elliptical
Galaxy](/wiki/Sagittarius_Dwarf_Elliptical_Galaxy "Sagittarius Dwarf
Elliptical Galaxy").[126]

It has been suggested that the Milky Way contains two different spiral
patterns: an inner one, formed by the Sagittarius arm, that rotates fast and
an outer one, formed by the Carina and Perseus arms, whose rotation velocity
is slower and whose arms are tightly wound. In this scenario, suggested by
numerical simulations of the dynamics of the different spiral arms, the outer
pattern would form an outer
[pseudoring](/wiki/Galaxy_morphological_classification#De_Vaucouleurs_system
"Galaxy morphological classification"),[127] and the two patterns would be
connected by the Cygnus arm.[128]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Nessie_molecular_cloud.png/220px-
Nessie_molecular_cloud.png)](/wiki/File:Nessie_molecular_cloud.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nessie_molecular_cloud.png "Enlarge")

The long filamentary molecular cloud dubbed "Nessie" probably forms a dense
"spine" of the Scutum–Centarus Arm

Outside of the major spiral arms is the [Monoceros Ring](/wiki/Monoceros_Ring
"Monoceros Ring") (or Outer Ring), a ring of gas and stars torn from other
galaxies billions of years ago. However, several members of the scientific
community recently restated their position affirming the Monoceros structure
is nothing more than an over-density produced by the flared and warped [thick
disk](/wiki/Thick_disk "Thick disk") of the Milky Way.[129]

### Halo

The Galactic disk is surrounded by a [spheroidal halo](/wiki/Galactic_spheroid
"Galactic spheroid") of old stars and globular clusters, of which 90% lie
within 100,000 light-years (30 kpc) of the Galactic Center.[130] However, a
few globular clusters have been found farther, such as PAL 4 and AM1 at more
than 200,000 light-years from the Galactic Center. About 40% of the Milky
Way's clusters are on [retrograde orbits](/wiki/Retrograde_orbit "Retrograde
orbit"), which means they move in the opposite direction from the Milky Way
rotation.[131] The globular clusters can follow [rosette
orbits](/wiki/Rosette_orbit "Rosette orbit") about the Milky Way, in contrast
to the [elliptical orbit](/wiki/Elliptical_orbit "Elliptical orbit") of a
planet around a star.[132]

Although the disk contains dust that obscures the view in some wavelengths,
the halo component does not. Active [star formation](/wiki/Star_formation
"Star formation") takes place in the disk (especially in the spiral arms,
which represent areas of high density), but does not take place in the halo,
as there is little gas cool enough to collapse into stars.[18] [Open
clusters](/wiki/Open_cluster "Open cluster") are also located primarily in the
disk.[133]

Discoveries in the early 21st century have added dimension to the knowledge of
the Milky Way's structure. With the discovery that the disk of the Andromeda
Galaxy (M31) extends much further than previously thought,[134] the
possibility of the disk of the Milky Way extending further is apparent, and
this is supported by evidence from the discovery of the Outer Arm extension of
the [Cygnus Arm](/wiki/Cygnus_Arm "Cygnus Arm")[118][135] and of a similar
extension of the [Scutum-Centaurus Arm](/wiki/Scutum-Centaurus_Arm "Scutum-
Centaurus Arm").[136] With the discovery of the [Sagittarius Dwarf Elliptical
Galaxy](/wiki/Sagittarius_Dwarf_Elliptical_Galaxy "Sagittarius Dwarf
Elliptical Galaxy") came the discovery of a ribbon of galactic debris as the
polar orbit of the dwarf and its interaction with the Milky Way tears it
apart. Similarly, with the discovery of the [Canis Major Dwarf
Galaxy](/wiki/Canis_Major_Dwarf_Galaxy "Canis Major Dwarf Galaxy"), it was
found that a ring of galactic debris from its interaction with the Milky Way
encircles the Galactic disk.

The [Sloan Digital Sky Survey](/wiki/Sloan_Digital_Sky_Survey "Sloan Digital
Sky Survey") of the northern sky shows a huge and diffuse structure (spread
out across an area around 5,000 times the size of a full moon) within the
Milky Way that does not seem to fit within current models. The collection of
stars rises close to perpendicular to the plane of the spiral arms of the
Milky Way. The proposed likely interpretation is that a [dwarf
galaxy](/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy "Dwarf galaxy") is merging with the Milky Way. This
galaxy is tentatively named the [Virgo Stellar
Stream](/wiki/Virgo_Stellar_Stream "Virgo Stellar Stream") and is found in the
direction of Virgo about 30,000 light-years (9 kpc) away.[137]

#### Gaseous halo

In addition to the stellar halo, the [Chandra X-ray
Observatory](/wiki/Chandra_X-ray_Observatory "Chandra X-ray Observatory"),
[XMM-Newton](/wiki/XMM-Newton "XMM-Newton"), and
[_Suzaku_](/wiki/Suzaku_\(satellite\) "Suzaku \(satellite\)") have provided
evidence that there is a gaseous halo with a large amount of hot gas. The halo
extends for hundreds of thousand of light years, much further than the stellar
halo and close to the distance of the Large and Small [Magellanic
Clouds](/wiki/Magellanic_Clouds "Magellanic Clouds"). The mass of this hot
halo is nearly equivalent to the mass of the Milky Way itself.[138][139][140]
The temperature of this halo gas is between 1 and 2.5 million K (1.8 and 4.5
million oF).[141]

Observations of distant galaxies indicate that the Universe had about one-
sixth as much [baryonic](/wiki/Baryon "Baryon") (ordinary) matter as dark
matter when it was just a few billion years old. However, only about half of
those baryons are accounted for in the modern Universe based on observations
of nearby galaxies like the Milky Way.[142] If the finding that the mass of
the halo is comparable to the mass of the Milky Way is confirmed, it could be
the identity of the missing baryons around the Milky Way.[142]

### Sun’s location and neighborhood

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Galactic_longitude.JPG/220px-
Galactic_longitude.JPG)](/wiki/File:Galactic_longitude.JPG)

Diagram of the Sun’s location in the Milky Way. The angles represent
longitudes in the [galactic coordinate
system](/wiki/Galactic_coordinate_system "Galactic coordinate system").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/3_Solar_Interstellar_Neighborhood_%28ELitU%29.png/220px-3_Solar_Interstellar_Neighborhood_%28ELitU%29.png)](/wiki/File:3_Solar_Interstellar_Neighborhood_\(ELitU\).png)

Diagram of the stars in the Solar neighborhood

The [Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun") is near the inner rim of the [Orion
Arm](/wiki/Orion_Arm "Orion Arm"), within the [Local Fluff](/wiki/Local_Fluff
"Local Fluff") of the [Local Bubble](/wiki/Local_Bubble "Local Bubble"), and
in the [Gould Belt](/wiki/Gould_Belt "Gould Belt"), at a distance of 26.4 ±
1.0 kly (8.09 ± 0.31 kpc)[15][16][17] from the Galactic Center. The Sun is
currently 5–30 parsecs (16–98 ly) from the central plane of the Galactic
disk.[143] The distance between the local arm and the next arm out, the
[Perseus Arm](/wiki/Perseus_Arm "Perseus Arm"), is about 2,000 parsecs (6,500
ly).[144] The Sun, and thus the Solar System, is located in the Milky Way's
[galactic habitable zone](/wiki/Galactic_habitable_zone "Galactic habitable
zone").

There are about 208 stars brighter than [absolute
magnitude](/wiki/Absolute_magnitude "Absolute magnitude") 8.5 within a sphere
with a radius of 15 parsecs (49 ly) from the Sun, giving a density of one star
per 69 cubic parsecs, or one star per 2,360 cubic light-years (from [List of
nearest bright stars](/wiki/List_of_nearest_bright_stars "List of nearest
bright stars")). On the other hand, there are 64 known stars (of any
magnitude, not counting 4 [brown dwarfs](/wiki/Brown_dwarf "Brown dwarf"))
within 5 parsecs (16 ly) of the Sun, giving a density of about one star per
8.2 cubic parsecs, or one per 284 cubic light-years (from [List of nearest
stars](/wiki/List_of_nearest_stars "List of nearest stars")). This illustrates
the fact that there are far more faint stars than bright stars: in the entire
sky, there are about 500 stars brighter than [apparent
magnitude](/wiki/Apparent_magnitude "Apparent magnitude") 4 but 15.5 million
stars brighter than apparent magnitude 14.[145]

The apex of the Sun's way, or the [solar apex](/wiki/Solar_apex "Solar apex"),
is the direction that the Sun travels through space in the Milky Way. The
general direction of the Sun's Galactic motion is towards the star
[Vega](/wiki/Vega "Vega") near the constellation of
[Hercules](/wiki/Hercules_\(constellation\) "Hercules \(constellation\)"), at
an angle of roughly 60 sky degrees to the direction of the Galactic Center.
The Sun's orbit about the Milky Way is expected to be roughly elliptical with
the addition of perturbations due to the Galactic spiral arms and non-uniform
mass distributions. In addition, the Sun passes through the Galactic plane
approximately 2.7 times per orbit.[146] This is very similar to how a [simple
harmonic oscillator](/wiki/Simple_harmonic_oscillator "Simple harmonic
oscillator") works with no drag force (damping) term. These oscillations were
until recently thought to coincide with [mass lifeform
extinction](/wiki/Mass_extinction "Mass extinction") periods on Earth.[147]
However, a reanalysis of the effects of the Sun's transit through the spiral
structure based on CO data has failed to find a correlation.[148]

It takes the Solar System about 240 million years to complete one orbit of the
Milky Way (a [galactic year](/wiki/Galactic_year "Galactic year")),[18] so the
Sun is thought to have completed 18–20 orbits during its lifetime and 1/1250
of a revolution since the [origin of humans](/wiki/Origin_of_humans "Origin of
humans"). The [orbital speed](/wiki/Orbital_speed "Orbital speed") of the
Solar System about the center of the Milky Way is approximately 220 km/s
(490,000 mph) or 0.073% of the [speed of light](/wiki/Speed_of_light "Speed of
light"). The Sun moves through the heliosphere at 84,000 km/h (52,000 mph). At
this speed, it takes around 1,400 years for the Solar System to travel a
distance of 1 light-year, or 8 days to travel 1 AU ([astronomical
unit](/wiki/Astronomical_unit "Astronomical unit")).[149] The Solar System is
headed in the direction of the zodiacal constellation Scorpius, which follows
the ecliptic.[150]

### Galactic rotation

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Rotation_curve_%28Milky_Way%29.JPG/200px-
Rotation_curve_%28Milky_Way%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Rotation_curve_\(Milky_Way\).JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Rotation_curve_\(Milky_Way\).JPG "Enlarge")

[Galaxy rotation curve](/wiki/Galaxy_rotation_curve "Galaxy rotation curve")
for the Milky Way. Vertical axis is speed of rotation about the Galactic
Center. Horizontal axis is distance from the Galactic Center in kpcs. The Sun
is marked with a yellow ball. The observed curve of speed of rotation is blue.
The predicted curve based upon stellar mass and gas in the Milky Way is red.
Scatter in observations roughly indicated by gray bars. The difference is due
to dark matter.[36][151][152]

The stars and gas in the Milky Way rotate about its center
[differentially](/wiki/Differential_rotation "Differential rotation"), meaning
that the rotation period varies with location. As is typical for spiral
galaxies, the orbital speed of most stars in the Milky Way does not depend
strongly on their distance from the center. Away from the central bulge or
outer rim, the typical stellar orbital speed is between 210 and 240 km/s
(470,000 and 540,000 mph).[153] Hence the [orbital
period](/wiki/Orbital_period "Orbital period") of the typical star is directly
proportional only to the length of the path traveled. This is unlike the
situation within the Solar System, where two-body gravitational dynamics
dominate, and different orbits have significantly different velocities
associated with them. The rotation curve (shown in the figure) describes this
rotation. Toward the center of the Milky Way the orbit speeds are too low,
whereas beyond 7 kpcs the speeds are too high to match what would be expected
from the universal law of gravitation.

If the Milky Way contained only the mass observed in stars, gas, and other
baryonic (ordinary) matter, the rotation speed would decrease with distance
from the center. However, the observed curve is relatively flat, indicating
that there is additional mass that cannot be detected directly with
electromagnetic radiation. This inconsistency is attributed to dark
matter.[36] The rotation curve of the Milky Way agrees with the [universal
rotation curve](/wiki/Universal_rotation_curve "Universal rotation curve") of
spiral galaxies, the best evidence for the existence of [dark
matter](/wiki/Dark_matter "Dark matter") in galaxies. Alternatively, a
minority of astronomers propose that a [modification of the law of
gravity](/wiki/MOND "MOND") may explain the observed rotation curve.[154]

Main article: [Galaxy formation and
evolution](/wiki/Galaxy_formation_and_evolution "Galaxy formation and
evolution")

The Milky Way began as one or several small overdensities in the mass
distribution in the [Universe](/wiki/Universe "Universe") shortly after the
[Big Bang](/wiki/Big_Bang "Big Bang").[155] Some of these overdensities were
the seeds of globular clusters in which the oldest remaining stars in what is
now the Milky Way formed. Nearly half the matter in the Milky Way may have
come from other distant galaxies.[155] Nonetheless, these stars and clusters
now comprise the stellar halo of the Milky Way. Within a few billion years of
the birth of the first stars, the mass of the Milky Way was large enough so
that it was spinning relatively quickly. Due to [conservation of angular
momentum](/wiki/Conservation_of_angular_momentum "Conservation of angular
momentum"), this led the gaseous interstellar medium to collapse from a
roughly spheroidal shape to a disk. Therefore, later generations of stars
formed in this spiral disk. Most younger stars, including the Sun, are
observed to be in the disk.[156][157]

Since the first stars began to form, the Milky Way has grown through both
[galaxy mergers](/wiki/Galaxy_merger "Galaxy merger") (particularly early in
the Milky Way's growth) and accretion of gas directly from the Galactic
halo.[157] The Milky Way is currently accreting material from two of its
nearest satellite galaxies, the [Large](/wiki/Large_Magellanic_Cloud "Large
Magellanic Cloud") and [Small](/wiki/Small_Magellanic_Cloud "Small Magellanic
Cloud") Magellanic Clouds, through the [Magellanic
Stream](/wiki/Magellanic_Stream "Magellanic Stream"). Direct accretion of gas
is observed in [high-velocity clouds](/wiki/High-velocity_cloud "High-velocity
cloud") like the [Smith Cloud](/wiki/Smith_Cloud "Smith Cloud").[158][159]
However, properties of the Milky Way such as stellar mass, [angular
momentum](/wiki/Angular_momentum "Angular momentum"), and
[metallicity](/wiki/Metallicity "Metallicity") in its outermost regions
suggest it has undergone no mergers with large galaxies in the last 10 billion
years. This lack of recent major mergers is unusual among similar spiral
galaxies; its neighbour the Andromeda Galaxy appears to have a more typical
history shaped by more recent mergers with relatively large
galaxies.[160][161]

According to recent studies, the Milky Way as well as the Andromeda Galaxy lie
in what in the [galaxy color–magnitude
diagram](/wiki/Galaxy_color%E2%80%93magnitude_diagram "Galaxy color–magnitude
diagram") is known as the "green valley", a region populated by galaxies in
transition from the "blue cloud" (galaxies actively forming new stars) to the
"red sequence" (galaxies that lack star formation). Star-formation activity in
green valley galaxies is slowing as they run out of star-forming gas in the
interstellar medium. In simulated galaxies with similar properties, star
formation will typically have been extinguished within about five billion
years from now, even accounting for the expected, short-term increase in the
rate of star formation due to the collision between both the Milky Way and the
Andromeda Galaxy.[162] In fact, measurements of other galaxies similar to the
Milky Way suggest it is among the reddest and brightest spiral galaxies that
are still forming new stars and it is just slightly bluer than the bluest red
sequence galaxies.[163]

### Age and cosmological history

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/A_firestorm_of_star_birth_%28artist%E2%80%99s_illustration%29.jpg/150px-
A_firestorm_of_star_birth_%28artist%E2%80%99s_illustration%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_firestorm_of_star_birth_\(artist%E2%80%99s_illustration\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_firestorm_of_star_birth_\(artist%E2%80%99s_illustration\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Night sky from a hypothetical planet within the Milky Way 10 billion years
ago.[164]

Globular clusters are among the oldest objects in the Milky Way, which thus
set a lower limit on the age of the Milky Way. The ages of individual stars in
the Milky Way can be estimated by measuring the abundance of long-lived
[radioactive elements](/wiki/Radioactive_element "Radioactive element") such
as [thorium-232](/wiki/Thorium-232 "Thorium-232") and
[uranium-238](/wiki/Uranium-238 "Uranium-238"), then comparing the results to
estimates of their original abundance, a technique called
[nucleocosmochronology](/wiki/Nucleocosmochronology "Nucleocosmochronology").
These yield values of about 12.5 ± 3 billion years for [CS
31082-001](/wiki/Cayrel%27s_Star "Cayrel's Star")[165] and 13.8 ± 4 billion
years for [BD +17° 3248](/wiki/BD_%2B17%C2%B0_3248 "BD +17° 3248").[166] Once
a [white dwarf](/wiki/White_dwarf "White dwarf") is formed, it begins to
undergo radiative cooling and the surface temperature steadily drops. By
measuring the temperatures of the coolest of these white dwarfs and comparing
them to their expected initial temperature, an age estimate can be made. With
this technique, the age of the globular cluster M4 was estimated as 12.7 ± 0.7
billion years. Age estimates of the oldest of these clusters gives a best fit
estimate of 12.6 billion years, and a 95% confidence upper limit of 16 billion
years.[167]

Several individual stars have been found in the Milky Way's halo with measured
ages very close to the 13.80-billion-year [age of the
Universe](/wiki/Age_of_the_Universe "Age of the Universe"). In 2007, a star in
the galactic halo, [HE 1523-0901](/wiki/HE_1523-0901 "HE 1523-0901"), was
estimated to be about 13.2 billion years old. As the oldest known object in
the Milky Way at that time, this measurement placed a lower limit on the age
of the Milky Way.[168] This estimate was made using the UV-Visual Echelle
Spectrograph of the [Very Large Telescope](/wiki/Very_Large_Telescope "Very
Large Telescope") to [measure](/wiki/Measurement "Measurement") the relative
strengths of [spectral lines](/wiki/Spectral_line "Spectral line") caused by
the presence of [thorium](/wiki/Thorium "Thorium") and other
[elements](/wiki/Chemical_element "Chemical element") created by the
[R-process](/wiki/R-process "R-process"). The line strengths yield abundances
of different elemental [isotopes](/wiki/Isotope "Isotope"), from which an
estimate of the age of the star can be derived using
[nucleocosmochronology](/wiki/Nucleocosmochronology
"Nucleocosmochronology").[168] Another star, [HD 140283](/wiki/HD_140283 "HD
140283"), is 14.5 ± 0.7 billion years old.[9][169]

The age of stars in the galactic [thin disk](/wiki/Thin_disk "Thin disk") has
also been estimated using nucleocosmochronology. Measurements of thin disk
stars yield an estimate that the thin disk formed 8.8 ± 1.7 billion years ago.
These measurements suggest there was a hiatus of almost 5 billion years
between the formation of the [galactic halo](/wiki/Galactic_halo "Galactic
halo") and the thin disk.[170] Recent analysis of the chemical signatures of
thousands of stars suggests that stellar formation might have dropped by an
order of magnitude at the time of disk formation, 10 to 8 billion years ago,
when interstellar gas was too hot to form new stars at the same rate as
before.[171]

The satellite galaxies surrounding the Milky way are not randomly distributed,
but seemed to be the result of a break-up of some larger system producing a
ring structure 500,000 light years in diameter and 50,000 light years
wide.[172] Close encounters between galaxies, like that expected in 4 billion
years with the Andromeda Galaxy rips off huge tails of gas, which, over time
can coalesce to form dwarf galaxies in a ring at right angles to the main
disc.[173]

## Environment

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/5_Local_Galactic_Group_%28ELitU%29.png/220px-5_Local_Galactic_Group_%28ELitU%29.png)](/wiki/File:5_Local_Galactic_Group_\(ELitU\).png)

Diagram of the galaxies in the [Local Group](/wiki/Local_Group "Local Group")
relative to the Milky Way

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/6_Virgo_Supercluster_%28ELitU%29.png/220px-6_Virgo_Supercluster_%28ELitU%29.png)](/wiki/File:6_Virgo_Supercluster_\(ELitU\).png)

The position of the Local Group within the [Virgo
Supercluster](/wiki/Virgo_Supercluster "Virgo Supercluster")

Main article: [Local Group](/wiki/Local_Group "Local Group")

The Milky Way and the [Andromeda Galaxy](/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy "Andromeda
Galaxy") are a [binary system](/wiki/Binary_system_\(astronomy\) "Binary
system \(astronomy\)") of giant spiral galaxies belonging to a group of 50
closely bound galaxies known as the [Local Group](/wiki/Local_Group "Local
Group"), surrounded by a Local Void, itself being part of the [Virgo
Supercluster](/wiki/Virgo_Supercluster "Virgo Supercluster"). Surrounding the
Virgo Supercluster are a number of voids, devoid of many galaxies, the
Microscopium Void to the "north", the Sculptor Void to the "left", the [Bootes
Void](/wiki/Bootes_Void "Bootes Void") to the "right" and the Canes-Major Void
to the South. These voids change shape over time, creating filamentous
structures of galaxies. The Virgo Supercluster, for instance, is being drawn
towards the [Great Attractor](/wiki/Great_Attractor "Great Attractor"),[174]
which in turn forms part of a greater structure, called
[Laniakea](/wiki/Laniakea_Supercluster "Laniakea Supercluster").[175]

Two smaller galaxies and a number of [dwarf galaxies](/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy
"Dwarf galaxy") in the Local Group orbit the Milky Way. The largest of these
is the [Large Magellanic Cloud](/wiki/Large_Magellanic_Cloud "Large Magellanic
Cloud") with a diameter of 14,000 light-years. It has a close companion, the
[Small Magellanic Cloud](/wiki/Small_Magellanic_Cloud "Small Magellanic
Cloud"). The [Magellanic Stream](/wiki/Magellanic_Stream "Magellanic Stream")
is a stream of neutral [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen") gas extending
from these two small galaxies across 100° of the sky. The stream is thought to
have been dragged from the Magellanic Clouds in tidal interactions with the
Milky Way.[176] Some of the [dwarf galaxies orbiting the Milky
Way](/wiki/Milky_Way%27s_satellite_galaxies "Milky Way's satellite galaxies")
are [Canis Major Dwarf](/wiki/Canis_Major_Dwarf "Canis Major Dwarf") (the
closest), [Sagittarius Dwarf Elliptical
Galaxy](/wiki/Sagittarius_Dwarf_Elliptical_Galaxy "Sagittarius Dwarf
Elliptical Galaxy"), [Ursa Minor Dwarf](/wiki/Ursa_Minor_Dwarf "Ursa Minor
Dwarf"), [Sculptor Dwarf](/wiki/Sculptor_Dwarf "Sculptor Dwarf"), [Sextans
Dwarf](/wiki/Sextans_Dwarf "Sextans Dwarf"), [Fornax Dwarf](/wiki/Fornax_Dwarf
"Fornax Dwarf"), and [Leo I Dwarf](/wiki/Leo_I_Dwarf "Leo I Dwarf"). The
smallest dwarf galaxies of the Milky Way are only 500 light-years in diameter.
These include [Carina Dwarf](/wiki/Carina_Dwarf "Carina Dwarf"), [Draco
Dwarf](/wiki/Draco_Dwarf "Draco Dwarf"), and [Leo II
Dwarf](/wiki/Leo_II_\(dwarf_galaxy\) "Leo II \(dwarf galaxy\)"). There may
still be undetected dwarf galaxies that are dynamically bound to the Milky
Way, which is supported by the detection of nine new satellites of the Milky
Way in a relatively small patch of the night sky in 2015.[177] There are also
some dwarf galaxies that have already been absorbed by the Milky Way, such as
[Omega Centauri](/wiki/Omega_Centauri "Omega Centauri").[178]

In 2014 researchers reported that most satellite galaxies of the Milky Way
actually lie in a very large disk and orbit in the same direction.[179] This
came as a surprise: according to standard cosmology, the satellite galaxies
should form in dark matter halos, and they should be widely distributed and
moving in random directions. This discrepancy is still not fully
explained.[180]

In January 2006, researchers reported that the heretofore unexplained warp in
the disk of the Milky Way has now been mapped and found to be a ripple or
vibration set up by the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds as they orbit the
Milky Way, causing vibrations when they pass through its edges. Previously,
these two galaxies, at around 2% of the mass of the Milky Way, were considered
too small to influence the Milky Way. However, in a computer model, the
movement of these two galaxies creates a dark matter wake that amplifies their
influence on the larger Milky Way.[181]

Current measurements suggest the Andromeda Galaxy is approaching us at 100 to
140 km/s (220,000 to 310,000 mph). In 3 to 4 billion years, there may be an
[Andromeda–Milky Way collision](/wiki/Andromeda%E2%80%93Milky_Way_collision
"Andromeda–Milky Way collision"), depending on the importance of unknown
lateral components to the galaxies' relative motion. If they collide, the
chance of individual [stars colliding](/wiki/Stellar_collision "Stellar
collision") with each other is extremely low, but instead the two galaxies
will merge to form a single [elliptical galaxy](/wiki/Elliptical_galaxy
"Elliptical galaxy") or perhaps a large [disk galaxy](/wiki/Disk_galaxy "Disk
galaxy")[182] over the course of about a billion years.[183]

## Velocity

Although [special relativity](/wiki/Special_relativity "Special relativity")
states that there is no "preferred" [inertial frame of
reference](/wiki/Inertial_frame_of_reference "Inertial frame of reference") in
space with which to compare the Milky Way, the Milky Way does have a velocity
with respect to cosmological [frames of reference](/wiki/Frames_of_reference
"Frames of reference").

One such frame of reference is the [Hubble flow](/wiki/Hubble_flow "Hubble
flow"), the apparent motions of galaxy clusters due to the [expansion of
space](/wiki/Expansion_of_space "Expansion of space"). Individual galaxies,
including the Milky Way, have [peculiar velocities](/wiki/Peculiar_velocities
"Peculiar velocities") relative to the average flow. Thus, to compare the
Milky Way to the Hubble flow, one must consider a volume large enough so that
the expansion of the Universe dominates over local, random motions. A large
enough volume means that the mean motion of galaxies within this volume is
equal to the Hubble flow. Astronomers believe the Milky Way is moving at
approximately 630 km/s (1,400,000 mph) with respect to this local co-moving
frame of reference.[184] The Milky Way is moving in the general direction of
the [Great Attractor](/wiki/Great_Attractor "Great Attractor") and other
[galaxy clusters](/wiki/Galaxy_cluster "Galaxy cluster"), including the
[Shapley supercluster](/wiki/Shapley_supercluster "Shapley supercluster"),
behind it.[185] The Local Group (a cluster of gravitationally bound galaxies
containing, among others, the Milky Way and the Andromeda Galaxy) is part of a
[supercluster](/wiki/Supercluster "Supercluster") called the [Local
Supercluster](/wiki/Local_Supercluster "Local Supercluster"), centered near
the [Virgo Cluster](/wiki/Virgo_Cluster "Virgo Cluster"): although they are
moving away from each other at 967 km/s (2,160,000 mph) as part of the Hubble
flow, this velocity is less than would be expected given the 16.8 million pc
distance due to the gravitational attraction between the Local Group and the
Virgo Cluster.[186]

Another reference frame is provided by the [cosmic microwave
background](/wiki/Cosmic_microwave_background "Cosmic microwave background")
(CMB). The Milky Way is moving at 552 ± 6 km/s (1,235,000 ± 13,000 mph)[187]
with respect to the photons of the CMB, toward 10.5 right ascension, −24°
declination ([J2000](/wiki/J2000 "J2000") epoch, near the center of
[Hydra](/wiki/Hydra_\(constellation\) "Hydra \(constellation\)")). This motion
is observed by satellites such as the [Cosmic Background
Explorer](/wiki/Cosmic_Background_Explorer "Cosmic Background Explorer")
(COBE) and the [Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy
Probe](/wiki/Wilkinson_Microwave_Anisotropy_Probe "Wilkinson Microwave
Anisotropy Probe") (WMAP) as a dipole contribution to the CMB, as photons in
equilibrium in the CMB frame get [blue-shifted](/wiki/Doppler_effect "Doppler
effect") in the direction of the motion and [red-shifted](/wiki/Redshift
"Redshift") in the opposite direction.[187]

## Etymology and mythology

Main articles: [List of names for the Milky
Way](/wiki/List_of_names_for_the_Milky_Way "List of names for the Milky Way")
and [Milky Way (mythology)](/wiki/Milky_Way_\(mythology\) "Milky Way
\(mythology\)")

In Babylonia, the Milky Way was said to be the tail of [Tiamat](/wiki/Tiamat
"Tiamat"), set in the sky by [Marduk](/wiki/Marduk "Marduk") after he had
slain the salt water goddess. It is believed this account, from the [Enuma
Elish](/wiki/Enuma_Elish "Enuma Elish") had Marduk replace an earlier
[Sumerian](/wiki/Sumer "Sumer") story when [Enlil](/wiki/Enlil "Enlil") of
[Nippur](/wiki/Nippur "Nippur") had slain the goddess.

**Llys Dôn** (literally "The Court of [Dôn](/wiki/D%C3%B4n "Dôn")") is the
traditional [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") name for the
constellation [Cassiopeia](/wiki/Cassiopeia_\(constellation\) "Cassiopeia
\(constellation\)"). At least three of Dôn's children also have astronomical
associations: [Caer
Gwydion](/w/index.php?title=Caer_Gwydion&action=edit&redlink=1 "Caer Gwydion
\(page does not exist\)") ("The fortress of [Gwydion](/wiki/Gwydion
"Gwydion")") is the traditional Welsh name for the Milky Way, and [Caer
Arianrhod](/w/index.php?title=Caer_Arianrhod&action=edit&redlink=1 "Caer
Arianrhod \(page does not exist\)") ("The Fortress of
[Arianrhod](/wiki/Arianrhod "Arianrhod")") being the constellation of [Corona
Borealis](/wiki/Corona_Borealis "Corona Borealis").

In western culture the name "Milky Way" is derived from its appearance as a
dim un-resolved "milky" glowing band arching across the night sky. The term is
a translation of the [Classical Latin](/wiki/Classical_Latin "Classical
Latin") _via lactea_ , in turn derived from the [Hellenistic
Greek](/wiki/Hellenistic_Greek "Hellenistic Greek") γαλαξίας, short for
γαλαξίας κύκλος (_galaxías kýklos_ , "milky circle"). The [Ancient
Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek") γαλαξίας (_galaxias_) – from root
γαλακτ-, γάλα ("milk") + -ίας (forming adjectives) – is also the root of
"galaxy", the name for our, and later all such, collections of
stars.[25][188][189][190] In Greek mythology it was supposedly made from the
forceful suckling of [Heracles](/wiki/Heracles "Heracles"), when
[Hera](/wiki/Hera "Hera") acted as a [wetnurse](/wiki/Wetnurse "Wetnurse") for
the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero").

The Milky Way, or "milk circle", was just one of 11 "circles" the Greeks
identified in the sky, others being the [zodiac](/wiki/Zodiac "Zodiac"), the
[meridian](/wiki/Meridian_\(astronomy\) "Meridian \(astronomy\)"), the
[horizon](/wiki/Horizon "Horizon"), the [equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"),
the [tropics of Cancer and Capricorn](/wiki/Tropics_of_Cancer_and_Capricorn
"Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn"), [Arctic](/wiki/Arctic_circle "Arctic
circle") and [Antarctic circles](/wiki/Antarctic_circle "Antarctic circle"),
and two [colure](/wiki/Colure "Colure") circles passing through both
poles.[191]

## Astronomical history

See also: [Galaxy § Observation history](/wiki/Galaxy#Observation_history
"Galaxy")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Herschel-
Galaxy.png/220px-Herschel-Galaxy.png)](/wiki/File:Herschel-Galaxy.png)

[](/wiki/File:Herschel-Galaxy.png "Enlarge")

The shape of the Milky Way as deduced from star counts by [William
Herschel](/wiki/William_Herschel "William Herschel") in 1785; the Solar System
was assumed near center

In _[Meteorologica](/wiki/Meteorologica "Meteorologica")_ (DK 59 A80),
[Aristotle](/wiki/Aristotle "Aristotle") (384–322 BC) wrote that the [Greek
philosophers](/wiki/Greek_philosophy "Greek philosophy")
[Anaxagoras](/wiki/Anaxagoras "Anaxagoras") (c. 500–428 BC) and
[Democritus](/wiki/Democritus "Democritus") (460–370 BC) proposed that the
Milky Way might consist of distant [stars](/wiki/Star "Star").[192] However,
Aristotle himself believed the Milky Way to be caused by "the ignition of the
fiery exhalation of some stars which were large, numerous and close
together"[193] and that the "ignition takes place in the upper part of the
[atmosphere](/wiki/Atmosphere "Atmosphere"), in the region of the world which
is continuous with the heavenly motions."[194][195] The
[Neoplatonist](/wiki/Neoplatonism "Neoplatonism") philosopher [Olympiodorus
the Younger](/wiki/Olympiodorus_the_Younger "Olympiodorus the Younger") (c.
495–570 A.D.) criticized this view, arguing that if the Milky Way were
[sublunary](/wiki/Sublunary "Sublunary"), it should appear different at
different times and places on Earth, and that it should have
[parallax](/wiki/Parallax "Parallax"), which it does not. In his view, the
Milky Way is celestial. This idea would be influential later in the [Islamic
world](/wiki/Muslim_world "Muslim world").[196]

The [Persian](/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people") astronomer [Abū Rayhān
al-Bīrūnī](/wiki/Ab%C5%AB_Rayh%C4%81n_al-B%C4%ABr%C5%ABn%C4%AB "Abū Rayhān al-
Bīrūnī") (973–1048) proposed that the Milky Way is "a collection of countless
fragments of the nature of [nebulous](/wiki/Nebula "Nebula") stars".[197] The
[Andalusian](/wiki/Al-Andalus "Al-Andalus") astronomer
[Avempace](/wiki/Ibn_Bajjah "Ibn Bajjah") (d 1138) proposed the Milky Way to
be made up of many stars but appears to be a continuous image due to the
effect of [refraction](/wiki/Refraction "Refraction") in [Earth's
atmosphere](/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Earth "Atmosphere of Earth"), citing his
observation of a [conjunction](/wiki/Conjunction_\(astronomy_and_astrology\)
"Conjunction \(astronomy and astrology\)") of Jupiter and Mars in 1106 or 1107
as evidence.[195] [Ibn Qayyim Al-Jawziyya](/wiki/Ibn_Qayyim_Al-Jawziyya "Ibn
Qayyim Al-Jawziyya") (1292–1350) proposed that the Milky Way is "a myriad of
tiny stars packed together in the sphere of the fixed stars" and that these
stars are larger than [planets](/wiki/Planet "Planet").[198]

According to Jamil Ragep, the Persian astronomer [Naṣīr al-Dīn al-
Ṭūsī](/wiki/Nasir_al-Din_al-Tusi "Nasir al-Din al-Tusi") (1201–1274) in his
_Tadhkira_ writes: "The Milky Way, i.e. the Galaxy, is made up of a very large
number of small, tightly clustered stars, which, on account of their
concentration and smallness, seem to be cloudy patches. Because of this, it
was likened to milk in color."[199]

Actual proof of the Milky Way consisting of many stars came in 1610 when
[Galileo Galilei](/wiki/Galileo_Galilei "Galileo Galilei") used a
[telescope](/wiki/Optical_telescope "Optical telescope") to study the Milky
Way and discovered that it is composed of a huge number of faint
stars.[200][201] In a treatise in 1755, [Immanuel Kant](/wiki/Immanuel_Kant
"Immanuel Kant"), drawing on earlier work by [Thomas
Wright](/wiki/Thomas_Wright_\(astronomer\) "Thomas Wright
\(astronomer\)"),[202] speculated (correctly) that the Milky Way might be a
rotating body of a huge number of stars, held together by [gravitational
forces](/wiki/Gravitation "Gravitation") akin to the Solar System but on much
larger scales.[203] The resulting disk of stars would be seen as a band on the
sky from our perspective inside the disk. Kant also conjectured that some of
the [nebulae](/wiki/Nebula "Nebula") visible in the night sky might be
separate "galaxies" themselves, similar to our own. Kant referred to both the
Milky Way and the "extragalactic nebulae" as "island universes", a term still
current up to the 1930s.[204][205][206]

The first attempt to describe the shape of the Milky Way and the position of
the Sun within it was carried out by [William Herschel](/wiki/William_Herschel
"William Herschel") in 1785 by carefully counting the number of stars in
different regions of the visible sky. He produced a diagram of the shape of
the Milky Way with the Solar System close to the center.[207]

In 1845, [Lord Rosse](/wiki/William_Parsons,_3rd_Earl_of_Rosse "William
Parsons, 3rd Earl of Rosse") constructed a new telescope and was able to
distinguish between elliptical and spiral-shaped nebulae. He also managed to
make out individual point sources in some of these nebulae, lending credence
to Kant's earlier conjecture.[208]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pic_iroberts1.jpg/220px-
Pic_iroberts1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pic_iroberts1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pic_iroberts1.jpg "Enlarge")

Photograph of the "Great Andromeda Nebula" from 1899, later identified as the
[Andromeda Galaxy](/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy "Andromeda Galaxy")

In 1917, [Heber Curtis](/wiki/Heber_Curtis "Heber Curtis") had observed the
nova [S Andromedae](/wiki/S_Andromedae "S Andromedae") within the [Great
Andromeda Nebula](/wiki/Great_Andromeda_Nebula "Great Andromeda Nebula")
([Messier object](/wiki/Messier_object "Messier object") 31). Searching the
photographic record, he found 11 more [novae](/wiki/Nova "Nova"). Curtis
noticed that these novae were, on average, 10
[magnitudes](/wiki/Magnitude_\(astronomy\) "Magnitude \(astronomy\)") fainter
than those that occurred within the Milky Way. As a result, he was able to
come up with a distance estimate of 150,000 parsecs. He became a proponent of
the "island universes" hypothesis, which held that the spiral nebulae were
actually independent galaxies.[209] In 1920 the [Great
Debate](/wiki/Great_Debate_\(astronomy\) "Great Debate \(astronomy\)") took
place between [Harlow Shapley](/wiki/Harlow_Shapley "Harlow Shapley") and
Heber Curtis, concerning the nature of the Milky Way, spiral nebulae, and the
dimensions of the Universe. To support his claim that the Great Andromeda
Nebula is an external galaxy, Curtis noted the appearance of dark lanes
resembling the dust clouds in the Milky Way, as well as the significant
[Doppler shift](/wiki/Doppler_effect "Doppler effect").[210]

The controversy was conclusively settled by [Edwin Hubble](/wiki/Edwin_Hubble
"Edwin Hubble") in the early 1920s using the Mount Wilson observatory [2.5 m
(100 in) Hooker telescope](/wiki/Hooker_telescope "Hooker telescope"). With
the [light-gathering power](/wiki/Light-gathering_power "Light-gathering
power") of this new telescope, he was able to produce [astronomical
photographs](/wiki/Astrophotography "Astrophotography") that resolved the
outer parts of some spiral nebulae as collections of individual stars. He was
also able to identify some [Cepheid variables](/wiki/Cepheid_variable "Cepheid
variable") that he could use as a
[benchmark](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/benchmark "wikt:benchmark") to
estimate the distance to the nebulae. He found that the Andromeda Nebula is
275,000 parsecs from the Sun, far too distant to be part of the Milky
Way.[211][212]

### Mapping

The [ESA](/wiki/European_Space_Agency "European Space Agency") spacecraft
[Gaia](/wiki/Gaia_\(spacecraft\) "Gaia \(spacecraft\)") provides distance
estimates by determining the [parallax](/wiki/Parallax "Parallax") of a
billion stars and is mapping the Milky Way with four planned releases of maps
in 2022.[213][214]

## Notes

  1. **Jump up ^** Jay M. Pasachoff in his textbook _Astronomy: From the Earth to the Universe_ states the term _Milky Way_ should refer exclusively to the band of light that the galaxy forms in the [night sky](/wiki/Night_sky "Night sky"), while the galaxy should receive the full name _Milky Way Galaxy_. See:
     * [Pasachoff, Jay M.](/wiki/Jay_Pasachoff "Jay Pasachoff") (1994). _Astronomy: From the Earth to the Universe_. Harcourt School. p. 500. [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") [0-03-001667-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-03-001667-3 "Special:BookSources/0-03-001667-3").
  2. **Jump up ^** See also [Bortle Dark-Sky Scale](/wiki/Bortle_Dark-Sky_Scale "Bortle Dark-Sky Scale").
  3. **Jump up ^** For a photo see: ["Sagittarius A*: Milky Way monster stars in cosmic reality show"](http://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2003/0203long/). _Chandra X-ray Observatory_. Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. January 6, 2003. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20080317061809/http://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2003/0203long/) from the original on March 17, 2008. Retrieved May 20, 2012.

  1. **Jump up ^** Karachentsev et al. give a _blue_ absolute magnitude of −20.8. Combined with a [color index](/wiki/Color_index "Color index") of 0.55 estimated [here](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2014MNRAS.440..405M), an absolute visual magnitude of −21.35 (−20.8 − 0.55 = −21.35) is obtained. Note that determining the absolute magnitude of the Milky Way is very difficult, because Earth is inside it.

  45. **Jump up ^** The center of the Galaxy lies in the direction of the [constellation](/wiki/Constellation "Constellation") [Sagittarius](/wiki/Sagittarius_\(constellation\) "Sagittarius \(constellation\)"). From Sagittarius, the hazy band of white light appears to pass westward through the constellations of [Scorpius](/wiki/Scorpius "Scorpius"), [Ara](/wiki/Ara_\(constellation\) "Ara \(constellation\)"), [Norma](/wiki/Norma_\(constellation\) "Norma \(constellation\)"), [Triangulum Australe](/wiki/Triangulum_Australe "Triangulum Australe"), [Circinus](/wiki/Circinus "Circinus"), [Centaurus](/wiki/Centaurus "Centaurus"), [Musca](/wiki/Musca "Musca"), [Crux](/wiki/Crux "Crux"), [Carina](/wiki/Carina_\(constellation\) "Carina \(constellation\)"), [Vela](/wiki/Vela_\(constellation\) "Vela \(constellation\)"), [Puppis](/wiki/Puppis "Puppis"), [Canis Major](/wiki/Canis_Major "Canis Major"), [Monoceros](/wiki/Monoceros "Monoceros"), [Orion](/wiki/Orion_\(constellation\) "Orion \(constellation\)") and [Gemini](/wiki/Gemini_\(constellation\) "Gemini \(constellation\)"), [Taurus](/wiki/Taurus_\(constellation\) "Taurus \(constellation\)"), to the [Galactic anticenter](/wiki/Galactic_anticenter "Galactic anticenter") in [Auriga](/wiki/Auriga_\(constellation\) "Auriga \(constellation\)"). From there, it passes through [Perseus](/wiki/Perseus_\(constellation\) "Perseus \(constellation\)"), [Andromeda](/wiki/Andromeda_\(constellation\) "Andromeda \(constellation\)"), [Cassiopeia](/wiki/Cassiopeia_\(constellation\) "Cassiopeia \(constellation\)"), [Cepheus](/wiki/Cepheus_\(constellation\) "Cepheus \(constellation\)") and [Lacerta](/wiki/Lacerta "Lacerta"), [Cygnus](/wiki/Cygnus_\(constellation\) "Cygnus \(constellation\)"), [Vulpecula](/wiki/Vulpecula "Vulpecula"), [Sagitta](/wiki/Sagitta "Sagitta"), [Aquila](/wiki/Aquila_\(constellation\) "Aquila \(constellation\)"), [Ophiuchus](/wiki/Ophiuchus "Ophiuchus"), [Scutum](/wiki/Scutum_\(constellation\) "Scutum \(constellation\)"), and back to [Sagittarius](/wiki/Sagittarius_\(constellation\) "Sagittarius \(constellation\)").
